description.narrative: (i) Market development: The successful implementation of the project could spark the interest of other market players and evolve into a common practice. Furthermore, this could become an important stabilization mechanism for the Philippine financial sector and help IFC to address the current NPLs issues of its existing clients; (ii) Best practices: As part of the project IFC would promote international insolvency standards, creditors'' rights and collection practices for the resolution of the distressed assets; and (iii) Replication: Through this project, IFC would be helping to assign a market value to a NPL portfolio. If successful, the proposed project has the potential to be replicated by other entities in the EAP region.

The project entails an investment in equity and debt, along with strategic partners, to create a platform to acquire and service a Distressed Asset (DA) portfolio of Planters Development Bank (Plantersbank or the Bank). The portfolio will be acquired through a to-be-formed Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV). The DA portfolio contains non-perfoming loans (NPL) and real and other properties owned or acquired (ROPOAs) with a face value of around US$71 million. Through the proposed project, IFC can play a critical role to help re-activate the DA market in the Philippines, mobilize funding from the private sector to help address the limited capital currently available in the local NPL market, and provide Plantersbank with a mechanism for NPL resolution which will allow it to increase lending to its customers. The proposed project is part of IFCs Debt and Asset Recovery Program (DARP), a crisis response initiative approved by the Board in August 2009, which focuses on DAs, roll-over risk and restructurings. DARPs strategy is to revitalize financial systems through investments in DA and servicing companies / platforms.
